bioghist.p: John Curwen (1749-1825) was born in England and immigrated to Pennsylvania in 1784. His wife was Mary Fisher Curwen (1750-1818). In 1785 Curwen purchased lands in Lower Merion in Montgomery County, calling his new estate Walnut Hill. His son, Joseph Curwen (1778-1848), was an agent for Stephen Girard and was in partnership with William Shippen Willing, selling tea, dry goods, and Madeira wine. Another son, George Fisher Curwen I (1790-1847), spent a year in Stephen Girard's Philadelphia counting house and briefly represented a Baltimore mercantile house. In 1816 he traveled to Port au Prince overseeing cargo sales. Upon his return in 1817 Curwen assumed management of Walnut Hill. He married Elinor Hunter Ewing (1789-1879) in 1819. Their children were John Curwen, MD (1821-1901), Mary Curwen (1823-1903), Maskell Ewing Curwen (1825-1868), and George F. Curwen II (1828-1901). George F Curwen II was an oil tycoon and built the current Walnut Hill house in 1864 near the site of John Curwen's 18th century farmhouse. Edwin Forrest Durang designed the house and the builder was William Danley. The wife of George Curwen II was Emily Moore Beatty Curwen (1829-1907). Their children were: Samuel Moore Curwen (1859-1932), who worked for the Brill Company, and also spent time in the west purchasing land, working as a "cow puncher"; George Fisher Curwen III (1861-1945), John Curwen (1863-1949); Maskell Ewing Curwen (1867-1918); and Christine Curwen (1871-1901). George Fisher Curwen III married Helen Stoddard Osborne (1868-1959) in 1894. Their children were Elinor E. Curwen (b. 1896) and Alice Osborne Curwen McKeen (Mrs. Edward F. McKeen) (b. 1902). Elinor lived at Eltham on the family estate. From 1926 to 1931 she ran the New York office of Masquelier & Fils. From 1933 to 1937 she worked at Irving Trust Co., after which she returned home to stay with her parents in Villanova. Other families represented in the collection include Ewing, Beatty, Patterson, Moore, Tanner, Osborne, Stoddard, Leaming, Hunter, and Wynkoop.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of the Curwen family of Villanova, Pennsylvania. Materials include: correspondence; family financial records; diaries, commonplace books, poems, and other writings; notes on family history and family trees; recollections and personal narratives; wills and estate papers; a small number of photographs and cartes de visites; sketches; school papers and report cards; miscellaneous certificates; printed materials, such as newspaper clippings and family and parish histories; family bibles; wedding invitations; and obituaries. Materials related to Walnut Hill, the Curwen family estate, include: farm and house accounts; deeds, mortgages, and legal papers; blueprints of the subdivision of the estate; several sketches of estate buildings and ground plans; interior and exterior photographs; clippings of an Architectural Age article on the estate; and correspondence about subdivision of the property and ownership. There are also inventories made in 1946 of the furnishings of Spring iIll, the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Curwen. Materials related to lands in Western Pennsylvania owned by the Curwen family include: deeds and letters relating to the purchase of lands; a patent for 355 acres in Lycoming County, 1789; and additional patents from the 1790s for several parcels of land. The collection also includes letters to Joseph Curwen from Stephen Girard, 1810-1811, and business correspondence of Samuel Curwen (1859-1932) with miscellaneous bills related to his work for Brill Co.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
